elements.content: A series of enantiopure ruthenium­(II) polypyridyl complexes are reported that feature pendant pyridyl groups suitable for building larger self-assembled structures. The complexes are characterized in detail in solution using NMR spectroscopy, cyclic voltammetry, and photophysical methods and in the solid state using single-crystal X-ray crystallography. The complexes are luminescent, displaying long excited-state lifetimes that are quenched when the pendant pyridyl groups are protonated. Reaction with cadmium­(II) ions results in the formation of a mixed-metal one-dimensional coordination polymer, which was characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography.
elements.clean_text: A series of enantiopure ruthenium(II) polypyridyl complexes are reported that feature pendant pyridyl groups suitable for building larger self-assembled structures. The complexes are characterized in detail in solution using NMR spectroscopy, cyclic voltammetry, and photophysical methods and in the solid state using single-crystal X-ray crystallography. The complexes are luminescent, displaying long excited-state lifetimes that are quenched when the pendant pyridyl groups are protonated. Reaction with cadmium(II) ions results in the formation of a mixed-metal one-dimensional coordination polymer, which was characterized by single-crystal X-ray crystallography.

elements.content: Photo- and redox-active ruthenium­(II) polypyridyl complexes can be readily decorated with pendant pyridyl groups by cross-coupling reactions. The resulting complexes have long-lived excited states with emission that can be quenched by protonation of the pendant groups. Detailed structural, spectroscopic, and electrochemical studies are presented indicating these complexes are promising candidates for stimuli-responsive photoredox catalysts.
elements.clean_text: Photo- and redox-active ruthenium(II) polypyridyl complexes can be readily decorated with pendant pyridyl groups by cross-coupling reactions. The resulting complexes have long-lived excited states with emission that can be quenched by protonation of the pendant groups. Detailed structural, spectroscopic, and electrochemical studies are presented indicating these complexes are promising candidates for stimuli-responsive photoredox catalysts.

elements.content: The introduction of photo- and redox-active metal complexes into extended structures allows their useful properties to be combined with the structural integrity of coordination polymer frameworks or discrete molecular assemblies. One successful strategy for incorporation of metal complexes into extended structures is their use as metalloligands, where the periphery of a complex is decorated with metal-ion binding groups to allow controlled self-assembly when combined with labile metal ions. Palladium(0)-cross coupling reactions, either on free ligands or directly upon metal complexes, are an efficient means to synthesize metalloligands, including pyridyl-functionalized ligands, which have been used for molecular wires and sensing applications. Ruthenium­(II) complexes have attracted considerable research attention, with applications ranging from light harvesting and water splitting to luminescent materials and, more recently, photoredox catalysis. The prototypical photoactive complex [Ru­(bpy)3]2+ (where bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine), and related complexes, have been shown to facilitate visible light photoredox catalysis, with impressive performance demonstrated for various reaction types ranging from cycloadditions to reductive couplings. Examples of discrete molecular cages containing ruthenium­(II) centers remain rare, despite their potential to act as solution-state reaction vessels. However, [Ru­(bpy)3]2+-type units have been incorporated into extended materials suitable for photoredox catalysis, such as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), where they have been encapsulated, used as structural elements, or doped into MOF structures, including by postsynthetic modification. Some of these examples have been shown to be active as visible light catalysts for CO2 reduction, and others have shown promise for hydrogen production. Related cyclometalated iridium­(III) complexes have also been successfully built into cadmium­(II)- or copper­(II)-containing networks that show solid-state luminescence. To the best of our knowledge, examples of ruthenium­(II)-based photoredox catalysts that demonstrate stimulus–responsive behavior have not yet been reported, although these features might allow their catalytic properties to be controlled externally, such as in response to guest molecules. In this study, the preparation and characterization of a series of enantiopure ruthenium­(II) complexes that feature pendant groups capable of recognizing protons or metal ions is reported, together with their structural, redox, and photophysical properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The introduction of photo- and redox-active metal complexes into extended structures allows their useful properties to be combined with the structural integrity of coordination polymer frameworks or discrete molecular assemblies. One successful strategy for incorporation of metal complexes into extended structures is their use as metalloligands, where the periphery of a complex is decorated with metal-ion binding groups to allow controlled self-assembly when combined with labile metal ions. Palladium(0)-cross coupling reactions, either on free ligands or directly upon metal complexes, are an efficient means to synthesize metalloligands, including pyridyl-functionalized ligands, which have been used for molecular wires and sensing applications. Ruthenium(II) complexes have attracted considerable research attention, with applications ranging from light harvesting and water splitting to luminescent materials and, more recently, photoredox catalysis. The prototypical photoactive complex [Ru(bpy)3]2+ (where bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine), and related complexes, have been shown to facilitate visible light photoredox catalysis, with impressive performance demonstrated for various reaction types ranging from cycloadditions to reductive couplings. Examples of discrete molecular cages containing ruthenium(II) centers remain rare, despite their potential to act as solution-state reaction vessels. However, [Ru(bpy)3]2+-type units have been incorporated into extended materials suitable for photoredox catalysis, such as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), where they have been encapsulated, used as structural elements, or doped into MOF structures, including by postsynthetic modification. Some of these examples have been shown to be active as visible light catalysts for CO2 reduction, and others have shown promise for hydrogen production. Related cyclometalated iridium(III) complexes have also been successfully built into cadmium(II)- or copper(II)-containing networks that show solid-state luminescence. To the best of our knowledge, examples of ruthenium(II)-based photoredox catalysts that demonstrate stimulus-responsive behavior have not yet been reported, although these features might allow their catalytic properties to be controlled externally, such as in response to guest molecules. In this study, the preparation and characterization of a series of enantiopure ruthenium(II) complexes that feature pendant groups capable of recognizing protons or metal ions is reported, together with their structural, redox, and photophysical properties.

elements.content: The numbering scheme adopted for ligands 3 and 4 and complexes [Ru­(phen)2(X)]­(PF6)2 (X = 1–6) are shown in and . 1H and 13C­{1H} NMR assignments were made using two-dimensional (2D) NMR methods (COSY, ROESY, NOESY, HSQC, HMBC) and are unambiguous unless stated otherwise. cis-Ru­(phen)2Cl2 (phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) was prepared according to a modified literature procedure. [Ru­(phen)2(py)2]­Cl2, 4-pyridineboronic acid pinacol ester, and 4-ethynylpyridine were prepared according to the literature. Ligands 1, 2, 3, and 6 have been previously reported. Details of synthetic procedures can be found in the (Sections S2 and S3).

Experimental Section

General

The numbering scheme adopted for ligands 3 and 4 and complexes [Ru(phen)2(X)](PF6)2 (X = 1-6) are shown in  and . 1H and 13C{1H} NMR assignments were made using two-dimensional (2D) NMR methods (COSY, ROESY, NOESY, HSQC, HMBC) and are unambiguous unless stated otherwise. cis-Ru(phen)2Cl2 (phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) was prepared according to a modified literature procedure. [Ru(phen)2(py)2]Cl2, 4-pyridineboronic acid pinacol ester, and 4-ethynylpyridine were prepared according to the literature. Ligands 1, 2, 3, and 6  have been previously reported. Details of synthetic procedures can be found in the  (Sections S2 and S3).

Resolution of Complexes

Both Λ and Δ isomers of [Ru­(phen)2(py)2]­(PF6)2 were prepared following the procedure reported by Keene. Na(−)-AsOTart was prepared from d-(−)-tartaric acid following the reported procedure. Na­(+)-AsOTart was used to isolate [Λ-Ru­(phen)2(py)2]­(PF6)2, and Na(−)-AsOTart was used to isolate [Δ-Ru­(phen)2(py)2]­(PF6)2.

Single crystals of [Ru­(phen)2(2)]­(PF6)2, [Ru­(phen)2(3)]­(PF6)2, and [Ru­(phen)2(4)]­(PF6)2 were measured using a Bruker kappa-II CCD diffractometer at 150 K with an IμS Incoatec Microfocus Source and Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 723 Å). Single crystals of [Ru­(phen)2(1)]­(PF6)2, [Ru­(phen)2(5)]­(PF6)2, Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(4)]­(PF6)2, and ligand 2 were measured using Si <111> monochromated synchrotron X-ray radiation (λ = 0.710 23 Å) at the MX1 Beamline of the Australian Synchrotron, while single crystals of Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(2)]­(PF6)2 and {[Ru­(phen)­2­(4).CdCl3]­(PF6)}0.5 were measured using Si <111> monochromated synchrotron X-ray radiation (λ = 0.710 23 Å) at the MX2 Beamline of the Australian Synchrotron.
elements.clean_text: Single crystals of [Ru(phen)2(2)](PF6)2, [Ru(phen)2(3)](PF6)2, and [Ru(phen)2(4)](PF6)2 were measured using a Bruker kappa-II CCD diffractometer at 150 K with an IμS Incoatec Microfocus Source and Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710723 Å). Single crystals of [Ru(phen)2(1)](PF6)2, [Ru(phen)2(5)](PF6)2, Δ-[Ru(phen)2(4)](PF6)2, and ligand 2 were measured using Si <111> monochromated synchrotron X-ray radiation (λ = 0.71023 Å) at the MX1 Beamline of the Australian Synchrotron, while single crystals of Δ-[Ru(phen)2(2)](PF6)2 and {[Ru(phen)2(4).CdCl3](PF6)}0.5 were measured using Si <111> monochromated synchrotron X-ray radiation (λ = 0.71023 Å) at the MX2 Beamline of the Australian Synchrotron.

elements.content: A variety of [Ru­(phen)2(X)]­(PF6)2 complexes as shown in were prepared in this study, where phen = 1,10-phenanthroline and X = ligands 1–6. The ligands 5-bromo-2,2′-bipyridine (1) and 5,5′-dibromo-2,2′-bipyridine (2) were prepared as described in the literature, except purification was performed by recrystallization from 1:1 CHCl3/EtOH rather than by column chromatography. These ligands could be reacted directly to form ligands 3–6, with full details provided in the . Ligands 1 and 2 were reacted with cis-Ru­(phen)2Cl2 under microwave conditions in ethane-1,2-diol leading to isolated yields of 87% and 94% for the [Ru­(phen)2(1)]­(PF6)2 and [Ru­(phen)2(2)]­(PF6)2 complexes, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis of Complexes [Ru(phen)2(X)](PF6)2, (X = 1-6)

A variety of [Ru(phen)2(X)](PF6)2 complexes as shown in  were prepared in this study, where phen = 1,10-phenanthroline and X = ligands 1-6. The ligands 5-bromo-2,2'-bipyridine (1) and 5,5'-dibromo-2,2'-bipyridine (2) were prepared as described in the literature, except purification was performed by recrystallization from 1:1 CHCl3/EtOH rather than by column chromatography. These ligands could be reacted directly to form ligands 3-6, with full details provided in the . Ligands 1 and 2 were reacted with cis-Ru(phen)2Cl2 under microwave conditions in ethane-1,2-diol leading to isolated yields of 87% and 94% for the [Ru(phen)2(1)](PF6)2 and [Ru(phen)2(2)](PF6)2 complexes, respectively.

elements.content: Ruthenium­(II) complexes prepared in this study. py = 4-pyridyl.
elements.clean_text: 1  Ruthenium(II) complexes prepared in this study. py = 4-pyridyl.

elements.content: We note that extended heating of complexes containing 1 or 2 results in dehalogenation of the ligand, so particular care is required when performing coupling reactions upon these units. These building blocks were further elaborated with additional metal ion binding sites using Pd(0) cross-coupling reactions such as those we have described previously. Specifically, reaction of [Ru­(phen)2(1)]­(PF6)2 or [Ru­(phen)2(2)]­(PF6)2 with excess 4-pyridineboronic acid pinacol ester, Pd­(PPh3)4, and Cs2CO3 in degassed water/dimethylformamide (DMF) gave [Ru­(phen)2(3)]­(PF6)2 and [Ru­(phen)2(4)]­(PF6)2 with isolated yields of 71% and 73%, respectively ( and ). Similarly, the reaction of [Ru­(phen)2(1)]­(PF6)2 or [Ru­(phen)2(2)]­(PF6)2 with excess 4-ethynylpyridine, Pd­(PPh3)4, and CuI in degassed 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME)/DMF/NEt3 gave [Ru­(phen)2(5)]­(PF6)2 and [Ru­(phen)2(6)]­(PF6)2 with isolated yields of 60% and 54%, respectively ( and ). In all cases the complexes were purified by column chromatography (SiO2, acetonitrile/water/saturated KNO3(aq) mixtures), with the center of the main orange band being collected and concentrated with excess ammonium hexafluorophosphate to precipitate the target complexes as hexafluorophosphate salts.

Specifically, reaction of [Ru(phen)2(1)](PF6)2 or [Ru(phen)2(2)](PF6)2 with excess 4-pyridineboronic acid pinacol ester, Pd(PPh3)4, and Cs2CO3 in degassed water/dimethylformamide (DMF) gave [Ru(phen)2(3)](PF6)2 and [Ru(phen)2(4)](PF6)2 with isolated yields of 71% and 73%, respectively ( and ). Similarly, the reaction of [Ru(phen)2(1)](PF6)2 or [Ru(phen)2(2)](PF6)2 with excess 4-ethynylpyridine, Pd(PPh3)4, and CuI in degassed 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME)/DMF/NEt3 gave [Ru(phen)2(5)](PF6)2 and [Ru(phen)2(6)](PF6)2 with isolated yields of 60% and 54%, respectively ( and ). In all cases the complexes were purified by column chromatography (SiO2, acetonitrile/water/saturated KNO3(aq) mixtures), with the center of the main orange band being collected and concentrated with excess ammonium hexafluorophosphate to precipitate the target complexes as hexafluorophosphate salts.

elements.content: Each of the [Ru­(phen)2(X)]­(PF6)2 complexes (X = 1–6) was characterized in solution using 2D multinuclear NMR techniques to allow unambiguous assignment of both 1H and 13C NMR signals. To assign the signals corresponding to the protons of the phen ligands in the monosubstituted complexes [Ru­(phen)2(1)]2+, [Ru­(phen)2(3)]2+, and [Ru­(phen)2(5)]2+, one-dimensional (1D) selective nuclear Overhauser effect (NOE) experiments were performed as previously described ( Section S5 Figures S39 and S40). The 1H NMR spectra and assignments are shown in .
elements.clean_text:
Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Characterization

Each of the [Ru(phen)2(X)](PF6)2 complexes (X = 1-6) was characterized in solution using 2D multinuclear NMR techniques to allow unambiguous assignment of both 1H and 13C NMR signals. To assign the signals corresponding to the protons of the phen ligands in the monosubstituted complexes [Ru(phen)2(1)]2+, [Ru(phen)2(3)]2+, and [Ru(phen)2(5)]2+, one-dimensional (1D) selective nuclear Overhauser effect (NOE) experiments were performed as previously described ( Section S5 Figures S39 and S40). The 1H NMR spectra and assignments are shown in .

elements.content: Some general trends can be noted by comparison of these 1H NMR spectra. First, the introduction of substituents onto the 5,5′-positions of the bipyridine ligand has a similar influence on the adjacent signals in both the mono- and disubstituted complexes. As examples, the HA4 and HA6 signals (see and for numbering) are shifted downfield consistently between the two series, relative to the parent [Ru­(phen)2(bpy)]2+ complex. Introduction of the bromo substituent results in small downfield shifts for the HA6 proton (Δδ +0.08 ppm for [Ru­(phen)2(1)]2+and +0.04 ppm for [Ru­(phen)2(2)]2+), and more significant downfield shifts for the HA4 signals (Δδ +0.18 ppm for [Ru­(phen)2(1)]2+ and +0.17 ppm for [Ru­(phen)2(2)]2+). Similar trends were observed upon introduction of pyridyl groups, with downfield shifts for the HA6 proton (Δδ +0.19 ppm and +0.20 ppm); and for the HA4 protons (Δδ by +0.30 and +0.33 ppm), for the monosubstituted ([Ru­(phen)2(3)]2+) and disubstituted ([Ru­(phen)2(4)]2+) complexes respectively, relative to the parent [Ru­(phen)2(bpy)]2+ complex. The HA4 and HA6 signals also displayed similar trends on the introduction of acetylenepyridyl groups in [Ru­(phen)2(5)]2+ and [Ru­(phen)2(6)]2+. In the monosubstituted cases, the signals for the unsubstituted pyridyl group are largely unaffected upon introduction of substituents on the other ring, and these electronic effects are entirely as expected.

Introduction of the bromo substituent results in small downfield shifts for the HA6 proton (Δδ +0.08 ppm for [Ru(phen)2(1)]2+and +0.04 ppm for [Ru(phen)2(2)]2+), and more significant downfield shifts for the HA4 signals (Δδ +0.18 ppm for [Ru(phen)2(1)]2+ and +0.17 ppm for [Ru(phen)2(2)]2+). Similar trends were observed upon introduction of pyridyl groups, with downfield shifts for the HA6 proton (Δδ +0.19 ppm and +0.20 ppm); and for the HA4 protons (Δδ by +0.30 and +0.33 ppm), for the monosubstituted ([Ru(phen)2(3)]2+) and disubstituted ([Ru(phen)2(4)]2+) complexes respectively, relative to the parent [Ru(phen)2(bpy)]2+ complex. In the monosubstituted cases, the signals for the unsubstituted pyridyl group are largely unaffected upon introduction of substituents on the other ring, and these electronic effects are entirely as expected.

elements.content: More interesting to note are the changes in the phenanthroline 1H NMR signals, which are effectively influenced primarily by through-space effects and are sensitive to changes in coordination geometry. Let us start by considering the protons adjacent to the phenanthroline nitrogen atoms, which we labeled HC2 and HC2′ in the disubstituted complexes. The HC2′ signal, which is on the ring trans to the equivalent phenanthroline ligand, is shifted downfield (+0.12 and +0.09 ppm for [Ru­(phen)2(4)]2+ and [Ru­(phen)­(6)]2+, respectively, relative to [Ru­(phen)2(bpy)]2+), whereas the HC2′ signal, which is on the ring trans to the bipyridine ligand, is essentially unaffected in [Ru­(phen)2(4)]2+ (Δδ +0.03) but shifted upfield in [Ru­(phen)­(6)]2+ (Δδ −0.08 ppm) relative to [Ru­(phen)2(bpy)]2+.
elements.clean_text: More interesting to note are the changes in the phenanthroline 1H NMR signals, which are effectively influenced primarily by through-space effects and are sensitive to changes in coordination geometry. Let us start by considering the protons adjacent to the phenanthroline nitrogen atoms, which we labeled HC2 and HC2'  in the disubstituted complexes. The HC2'  signal, which is on the ring trans to the equivalent phenanthroline ligand, is shifted downfield (+0.12 and +0.09 ppm for [Ru(phen)2(4)]2+ and [Ru(phen)(6)]2+, respectively, relative to [Ru(phen)2(bpy)]2+), whereas the HC2' signal, which is on the ring trans to the bipyridine ligand, is essentially unaffected in [Ru(phen)2(4)]2+ (Δδ +0.03) but shifted upfield in [Ru(phen)(6)]2+ (Δδ -0.08 ppm) relative to [Ru(phen)2(bpy)]2+.

elements.content: If we consider the more complicated monosubstituted complexes it can be seen that the trends discussed above are broadly mirrored. First, it must be noted that the lower symmetry of these complexes results in four nonequivalent pyridyl rings corresponding to the phenanthroline ligands, labeled C, C′, C″, and C‴ (see for labeling). In these cases, pairs of signals overlap (ring C′ with ring C″; ring C with ring C‴), with the exception of the signals corresponding to the protons adjacent to the nitrogen atoms, HC2, HC2′ , HC2′′ , and HC2′′′ . To assign these nonequivalent signals, 1D selective NOE experiments were performed ( section S5 Figures S39 and S40). Specifically, the 1H NMR signals of the phenanthroline rings nearest to the substituted bpy ring (HC2 and HC2′′ ) show NOE coupling to the bipyridine HA6′ signal, in line with recent assignments of the analogous signals of related complexes. The signals that correspond to the protons close in space to the substituted bipyridyl ring (i.e., HC2 and HC2″) have similar chemical shifts to the analogous signals of the disubstituted complexes. For example, the HC2 signal is shifted downfield (Δδ = +0.10, +0.14, +0.11 ppm) in the monosubstituted complexes [Ru­(phen)2(1)]2+, [Ru­(phen)2(3)]2+, and [Ru­(phen)2(5)]2+, and similar shifts were observed in the analogous disubstituted complexes (Δδ = +0.04, +0.12, and +0.09 ppm, all relative to [Ru­(phen)2(bpy)]2+). The signals of phenanthroline rings close in space to the unsubstituted pyridyl ring (e.g., HC2′ and HC2′′′ ) are largely unaffected by the substitution (Δδ < 0.07 ppm), as might be expected.

In these cases, pairs of signals overlap (ring C' with ring C"; ring C with ring C‴), with the exception of the signals corresponding to the protons adjacent to the nitrogen atoms, HC2, HC2' , HC2'' , and HC2''' . To assign these nonequivalent signals, 1D selective NOE experiments were performed ( section S5 Figures S39 and S40). Specifically, the 1H NMR signals of the phenanthroline rings nearest to the substituted bpy ring (HC2 and HC2'' ) show NOE coupling to the bipyridine HA6'  signal, in line with recent assignments of the analogous signals of related complexes. The signals that correspond to the protons close in space to the substituted bipyridyl ring (i.e., HC2 and HC2") have similar chemical shifts to the analogous signals of the disubstituted complexes. For example, the HC2 signal is shifted downfield (Δδ = +0.10, +0.14, +0.11 ppm) in the monosubstituted complexes [Ru(phen)2(1)]2+, [Ru(phen)2(3)]2+, and [Ru(phen)2(5)]2+, and similar shifts were observed in the analogous disubstituted complexes (Δδ = +0.04, +0.12, and +0.09 ppm, all relative to [Ru(phen)2(bpy)]2+). The signals of phenanthroline rings close in space to the unsubstituted pyridyl ring (e.g., HC2'  and HC2''' ) are largely unaffected by the substitution (Δδ < 0.07 ppm), as might be expected.

elements.content: This pattern of NMR signals is likely common for unsymmetrical ruthenium­(II) polypyridyl complexes and offers some interesting insight into the structures of the complexes. The solid-state structures of these complexes (vide infra) show the complexes adopt near-ideal octahedral geometry, suggesting the observed solution-state NMR signal shifts are the result of electronic rather than steric effects. We expect these 1H NMR assignments to be general for a wide variety of related ruthenium­(II) polypyridyl complexes and will prove useful benchmarks for future NMR assignments.

elements.content: In complexes [Ru­(phen)2(3)]2+, [Ru­(phen)2(4)]2+, [Ru­(phen)2(5)]2+, and [Ru­(phen)2(6)]2+, the HB2 signals corresponding to protons on pendant pyridyl rings exhibit strong sensitivity to acid and water content and become extremely broad upon protonation. Similar behavior has been perceived in 4′-pyridyl decorated 2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine complexes of ruthenium­(II) and in bis­(2,2′-bipyridine)­(5,5′-(3-pyridyl)-2,2′-bipyridine) ruthenium­(II) complexes.

Similar behavior has been perceived in 4'-pyridyl decorated 2,2':6',2"-terpyridine complexes of ruthenium(II) and in bis(2,2'-bipyridine)(5,5'-(3-pyridyl)-2,2'-bipyridine) ruthenium(II) complexes.

Photophysical Studies

The solution-state absorption and emission spectra of the [Ru(phen)2(X)](PF6)2 complexes (X = 1-6) were measured in acetonitrile and are shown in . In each case an intense ligand-centered (LC) π-π* absorption is observed at 263 nm, as expected for ruthenium(II) polypyridyl complexes, in addition to typical spin-allowed 1MLCT d-π* absorption bands at lower energies (MLCT = metal-to-ligand charge transfer).

elements.content: In all complexes, these 1MLCT transitions range from 443 to 450 nm, which are similar to [Ru­(phen)2(bpy)]2+, which has a typical 1MLCT transition at 448 nm. Notably, these 1MLCT transitions are also slightly broader in comparison to [Ru­(phen)2(bpy)]2+, and additional bands are also apparent at longer wavelengths. For example, for [Ru­(phen)2(6)]2+, an additional peak is evident centered at 498 nm. This suggests the complexes exhibit multiple 1MLCT excited states, with the lowest-energy transition corresponding to a bpy-localized 1MLCT excited state, and the higher-energy bands corresponding to phen-localized 1MLCT exited-state states.

elements.content: For complexes with pendant pyridyl groups, the 1MLCT absorption was found to be sensitive to acid, with protonation resulting in a broadening of the band towards longer wavelengths, and a decreasing in the intensity of the absorption. Data for complex [Ru­(phen)2(4)]2+ is shown in , and related data for the other complexes can be found in the (Figures S44–S46). The introduction of an extended acetylene spacer also resulted in new ligand-centered transition, which decreases in energy and increases in intensity on going from mono- to disubstitution, yielding an intense absorption at 348 nm for the [Ru­(phen)2(6)]­(PF6)2 complex. Upon protonation of the pyridyl groups, this band undergoes a red shift to 359 nm with no appreciable change in intensity.

Most notably, as substituents are introduced onto the bipyridine unit, the peak emission wavelength is shifted to lower energy, with [Ru­(phen)2(6)]2+ having the lowest-energy emission at 696 nm, which is red-shifted by almost 90 nm with respect to the parent [Ru­(phen)2(bpy)]2+ complex.

In addition to the changes noted in the 1MLCT absorption, the corresponding 3MLCT emission of complexes containing appended pyridyl groups (i.e., [Ru­(phen)2(3)]2+ to [Ru­(phen)2(6)]2+) is quenched upon the addition of excess trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), due to protonation of the pendant nitrogen atoms. An example titration for [Ru­(phen)2(4)]­(PF6)2 is shown in , and data for the other complexes can be found in the (Figures S44–S46). Addition of acid had no significant effect on the absorption or emission of the bromo-functionalized complexes [Ru­(phen)2(1)]2+ and [Ru­(phen)2(2)]2+, as shown in , which confirms the interaction between the acid and noncoordinated pyridyl nitrogen atoms on the complexes is responsible for the observed changes in optical properties. The observed luminescence quenching can be attributed to the proximity of additional positive charge on the pendant pyridyl ring adjacent to the metal center, providing additional nonradiative deactivation pathways, and similar results have been observed for a [Ru­(bpy)2(2,2′-bipyrazine)]2+ complex, which also demonstrated significant emission quenching upon protonation.

elements.content: Solution photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) and 3MLCT excited state lifetimes (τ) were determined for the fully deprotonated complexes, together with several reference complexes measured under identical conditions as their bis-hexafluorophosphate salts in aerated acetonitrile, with results as summarized in . Each of the [Ru­(phen)2(X)]2+ complexes (X = 1–6) display room-temperature emission, with PLQY and τ values that are comparable to those of the [Ru­(bpy)3]2+ and [Ru­(phen)3]2+ complexes. Notably, the PLQY value we obtain for the former is also in excellent agreement with recent reports from the literature. By comparison to [Ru­(phen)2(bpy)]2+ as a model, the bromo-functionalized [Ru­(phen)2(1)]2+ and [Ru­(phen)2(2)]2+ complexes display slightly longer 3MLCT excited-state lifetimes of ca. 200 and 290 ns, respectively, primarily due to a decrease in the nonradiative deactivation rate constant (k nr). Similarly, complexes with pendant pyridyl groups also have slightly longer excited-state lifetimes ranging from ca. 170 to 245 ns. Considering the entire [Ru­(phen)2(X)]2+ series of complexes (X = 1–6), we also note that the nonsymmetric monosubstituted complexes (X = 1, 3, 5) have consistently higher radiative deactivation rate constants (k r) compared to the symmetrically disubstituted complexes (X = 2, 4, 6), although the reasons for these differences remain unclear.

elements.content: Lastly, as noted, the steady-state 3MLCT emission of the [Ru­(phen)2(3–4)]2+ complexes bearing pendant pyridyl groups is effectively quenched upon titration with TFA, and corresponding time-resolved emission profiles collected in the presence of excess acid displayed multiexponential decay behavior. In particular, a decrease in the observed lifetimes was noted, yielding better fits to a biexponential decay including shorter-lived components on the 10–20 ns time scale. This behavior can be readily attributed to the presence of competing excited-state protonation equilibria in solution, such as that observed for other ruthenium­(II) polypyridyl complexes including [Ru­(bpy)2(bpm)]2+ or [Ru­(bpy)2(bpz)]2+ (bpm = 2,2′-bipyrimidine, bpz = 2,2′-bipyrazine) featuring coordinated ligands with additional basic nitrogen atoms sensitive to aqueous solution pH.

elements.content: The electrochemical behavior of the complexes was investigated using cyclic voltammetry, with individual results summarized in , together with selected ruthenium­(II) reference complexes measured under identical conditions. All of the complexes display a reversible one-electron oxidation peak, corresponding to the metal-centered Ru­(II)/Ru­(III) redox couple, with E 1/2 values ranging from +0.93 to +0.97 V (vs Fc+/Fc) as expected based on the redox couples of typical Ru­(II)/Ru­(III) complexes. In all cases, the redox potential was shifted to more positive values upon going from mono to difunctionalized ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemistry

The electrochemical behavior of the complexes was investigated using cyclic voltammetry, with individual results summarized in , together with selected ruthenium(II) reference complexes measured under identical conditions. All of the complexes display a reversible one-electron oxidation peak, corresponding to the metal-centered Ru(II)/Ru(III) redox couple, with E 1/2 values ranging from +0.93 to +0.97 V (vs Fc+/Fc) as expected based on the redox couples of typical Ru(II)/Ru(III) complexes. In all cases, the redox potential was shifted to more positive values upon going from mono to difunctionalized ligands.

Data measured in this study, for literature values see ref .

For the [Ru­(phen)2(X)]2+ (X = 1–6) complexes, the first reduction process occurs within a potential range from −1.31 to −1.68 V (vs Fc+/Fc), and in all cases corresponds to a bipyridine-ligand-centered reduction. These values indicate the functionalized bipyridine ligands used in this study are all more readily reduced than the unfunctionalized bipyridine or phenanthroline ligands, which display their first ligand-based reductions in the range from −1.72 to −1.76 V under identical conditions. The bromo-functionalized derivatives [Ru­(phen)2(1)]2+ and [Ru­(phen)2(2)]2+ show an irreversible ligand-based reduction at −1.63 and −1.67 V, respectively, in addition to the expected series of three reversible ligand reductions at more negative potentials, while for the other complexes, a total of up to four reversible ligand-based reductions were observed. The band gaps calculated from electrochemical data using the first reversible oxidation and first reversible reduction suggest much lower values than those obtained from the 1MLCT absorption maxima, in agreement with the observed broad absorption data. For example, [Ru­(phen)2(6)]2+ shows an additional broad absorption band centered at 500 nm, which extends beyond 600 nm (<2.07 eV). As discussed previously, this suggests the intense 1MLCT absorption observed at ca. 445 nm for each of the complexes is associated with a phenanthroline-centered excited state, with broader bipyridine-centered 1MLCT absorptions located at lower energy. The emission from each complex can be attributed to this lower-lying bipyridine-centered 3MLCT level, and a very strong correlation is apparent when considering the calculated band gaps determined by cyclic voltammetry and the peak emission energies, as shown in .

elements.content: Complexes [Ru­(phen)2(1–6)]2+ were also able to be prepared as enantiopure isomers using adapted literature procedures. The enantiopure Λ- and Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(py)2]­(PF6)2 complexes were prepared using a literature procedure, and reaction of ligands 1 or 2 with these complexes under microwave conditions (160 °C, 30 min) in ethane-1,2-diol led to isolation of Λ- or Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(1)]­(PF6)2 and Λ- or Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(2)]­(PF6)2, respectively. Subsequent reaction of Λ- or Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(1)]­(PF6)2 or Λ- and Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(2)]­(PF6)2 under microwave conditions (120 °C, 1 h) with excess 4-pyridineboronic acid pinacol ester, Pd­(PPh3)4, and Cs2CO3 in degassed DME/DMF furnished enantiopure Λ- and Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(3)]­(PF6)2 or Λ- and Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(4)]­(PF6)2 with isolated yields of 74% and 76%, respectively. Similarly, reaction of Λ- and Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(1)]­(PF6)2 or Λ- and Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(2)]­(PF6)2 under microwave condition (120 °C, 1 h) with excess 4-(trimethylsilylethynyl)­pyridine, Pd­(PPh3)4, CuI, and K2CO3 in degassed MeOH/DMF/NEt3 gave Λ- or Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(5)]­(PF6)2 and Λ- or Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(6)]­(PF6)2 with isolated yields of 66% and 54%, respectively. Importantly, using microwave conditions resulted in significantly shorter reaction times compared to the more traditional coupling reaction conditions described for the racemic complexes reported in Section 3 of the . This method also showed no evidence of racemization.

Resolution of Complexes

Complexes [Ru(phen)2(1-6)]2+ were also able to be prepared as enantiopure isomers using adapted literature procedures. The enantiopure Λ- and Δ-[Ru(phen)2(py)2](PF6)2 complexes were prepared using a literature procedure, and reaction of ligands 1 or 2 with these complexes under microwave conditions (160 °C, 30 min) in ethane-1,2-diol led to isolation of Λ- or Δ-[Ru(phen)2(1)](PF6)2 and Λ- or Δ-[Ru(phen)2(2)](PF6)2, respectively. Subsequent reaction of Λ- or Δ-[Ru(phen)2(1)](PF6)2 or Λ- and Δ-[Ru(phen)2(2)](PF6)2 under microwave conditions (120 °C, 1 h) with excess 4-pyridineboronic acid pinacol ester, Pd(PPh3)4, and Cs2CO3 in degassed DME/DMF furnished enantiopure Λ- and Δ-[Ru(phen)2(3)](PF6)2 or Λ- and Δ-[Ru(phen)2(4)](PF6)2 with isolated yields of 74% and 76%, respectively. Similarly, reaction of Λ- and Δ-[Ru(phen)2(1)](PF6)2 or Λ- and Δ-[Ru(phen)2(2)](PF6)2 under microwave condition (120 °C, 1 h) with excess 4-(trimethylsilylethynyl)pyridine, Pd(PPh3)4, CuI, and K2CO3 in degassed MeOH/DMF/NEt3 gave Λ- or Δ-[Ru(phen)2(5)](PF6)2 and Λ- or Δ-[Ru(phen)2(6)](PF6)2 with isolated yields of 66% and 54%, respectively. Importantly, using microwave conditions resulted in significantly shorter reaction times compared to the more traditional coupling reaction conditions described for the racemic complexes reported in Section 3 of the . This method also showed no evidence of racemization.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray structures for the [Ru­(phen)2(1)]2+, [Ru­(phen)2(2)]2+, [Ru­(phen)2(3)]2+, [Ru­(phen)2(4)]2+, [Ru­(phen)2(5)]2+, Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(2)]2+, and Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(4)]2+ complexes were determined, and a single complex cation from each of the structures is shown in . In all cases, single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were grown by vapor diffusion of diethyl ether into an acetonitrile solution of complexes, except for the Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(2)]2+ complex, which was grown by vapor diffusion of diethyl ether into a solution of the complex in a mixture of acetonitrile and ethanol. In all of the X-ray structures obtained, the N–Ru–N bond angles and Ru–N bond lengths are unexceptional. In many cases, the complexes crystallize with water and/or solvent molecules, which often engage in hydrogen-bonding interactions with the pendant pyridyl groups.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

Single-crystal X-ray structures for the [Ru(phen)2(1)]2+, [Ru(phen)2(2)]2+, [Ru(phen)2(3)]2+, [Ru(phen)2(4)]2+, [Ru(phen)2(5)]2+, Δ-[Ru(phen)2(2)]2+, and Δ-[Ru(phen)2(4)]2+ complexes were determined, and a single complex cation from each of the structures is shown in . In all cases, single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were grown by vapor diffusion of diethyl ether into an acetonitrile solution of complexes, except for the Δ-[Ru(phen)2(2)]2+ complex, which was grown by vapor diffusion of diethyl ether into a solution of the complex in a mixture of acetonitrile and ethanol. In all of the X-ray structures obtained, the N-Ru-N bond angles and Ru-N bond lengths are unexceptional. In many cases, the complexes crystallize with water and/or solvent molecules, which often engage in hydrogen-bonding interactions with the pendant pyridyl groups.

elements.content: Single crystals of [Ru­(phen)2(1)]­(PF6)2·MeCN were crystallized in the C2/c space group containing one acetonitrile solvent molecule. Single crystals of {[Ru­(phen)2(2)]­(PF6)2}2 were crystallized in the Cc space group with two symmetry inequivalent complexes in the asymmetric unit. Single crystals of Δ-{[Ru­(phen)2(2)]­(PF6)2}2·H2O·EtOH were grown in the chiral P212121 space group with two symmetry inequivalent complexes in the asymmetric unit, which are nonetheless structurally very similar to each other and to that observed for the racemic crystal. To determine the absolute configuration, Byvoet pair calculations were performed using PLATON (Flack parameter = 0.028(2), Parsons quotient = 0.037(1), and Hooft y = 0.013). The results indicated that the absolute structure had been correctly assigned (see Section 10.6 of the for details). Single crystals of [Ru­(phen)2(3)]­(PF6)2 were crystallized in the P21/c space group with no solvent molecules present. The structure contains several short intermolecular contacts, including a 2.561 Å contact between the N atom of the pendant pyridine ring (N7) and the H27 proton of the phen ligand on an adjacent complex. A diagram of the crystal packing is shown in . Single crystals of [Ru­(phen)2(4)]­(PF6)2·3H2O were crystallized in the P1̅ space group, and the crystal packing for this complex is shown in . Most notably, the water molecules are engaged in several hydrogen-bonding interactions with the pendant pyridyl groups, with both the O3 and O4 oxygen atoms forming a dimer through hydrogen bonding. The N7···H2B, O2···H1, N8···H3B, O4···H3A, and O3···H4B contact distances are 1.922, 2.564, 2.321, 1.883, and 1.982 Å, respectively.

elements.content: Single crystals of Δ-{[Ru­(phen)2(4)]­(PF6)2}2·H2O·0.5Et2O were grown in the chiral P21 space group, containing two nonequivalent complexes in the asymmetric unit. The crystal structure contains one cocrystallized water molecule and a diethyl ether solvent molecule with 50% partial occupancy. The water molecule is involved in several hydrogen-bonding contacts between the pendant pyridyl rings and the phenanthroline ligand, as shown in . The hydrogen-bond contact distances are N15···H2A, N7···H2B, and O2···H88 are 2.130, 1.946, and 3.056 Å, respectively.

elements.content: Single crystals of [Ru­(phen)2(5)]­(PF6)2 were grown in the P1̅ space group, and the resulting crystal packing is shown in . In addition to hydrogen-bonding interactions between the N7 nitrogen atom of the pyridyl ring and hydrogens H32 and H38 of the phen ligand, π–π stacking between the rings of the bpy ligands is apparent. The distance between the centroid of the bipyridine ring attached to the alkyne spacer and the ring next to it to the plane of the bipyridine rings are 3.224 and 3.223 Å, respectively, and N7···H32 and N7···H38 distances are 2.826 and 2.578 Å, respectively.

elements.content: To consider the use of these complexes as building blocks for extended systems, one important factor is the angle between the vectors formed by the two donor atoms. In the cases of Δ-[Ru­(phen)2(4)]2+ and [Ru­(phen)2(4)]2+, this angle deviates slightly from linearity (159 and 169°, respectively) due to coordination of the central bpy unit to the ruthenium­(II) metal center. This deviation from linearity indicates both flexibility in the coordinated bpy ligand and also emphasizes the possibility of using these complexes to form discrete nanostructures. For the monosubstituted complexes [Ru­(phen)2(3)]2+ and [Ru­(phen)2(5)]2+, the deviation from linearity was estimated by the angle formed between the vectors of the pendant nitrogen to the carbon in the 4-position of the pyridyl ring and the central C–C bond of the bipyridine ligand (see Section 10.10). Angles of 164 and 169° were found for [Ru­(phen)2(3)]2+ and [Ru­(phen)2(5)]2+, again highlighting the flexibility of the coordinated ligand environment.

This deviation from linearity indicates both flexibility in the coordinated bpy ligand and also emphasizes the possibility of using these complexes to form discrete nanostructures. For the monosubstituted complexes [Ru(phen)2(3)]2+ and [Ru(phen)2(5)]2+, the deviation from linearity was estimated by the angle formed between the vectors of the pendant nitrogen to the carbon in the 4-position of the pyridyl ring and the central C-C bond of the bipyridine ligand (see  Section 10.10). elements.content: As a first attempt towards using the reported complexes as supramolecular building blocks, we reacted the [Ru­(phen)2(4)]­(PF6)2 complex with cadmium­(II) ions. Cadmium­(II) was selected, since this d10 metal ion commonly exhibits considerable flexibility in its coordination geometry and has been reliably used to form extended structures with a wide variety of organic linker units and also mixed-metal systems. Single crystals of {[Ru­(phen)2(4)-CdCl3]­(PF6)}0.5 were grown by slow diffusion of an ethanol solution of CdCl2 through an ethanol/nitromethane buffer layer containing two drops of trifluoroethanol into a solution of the rac-[Ru­(phen)2(4)]­(PF6)2 complex dissolved in nitromethane over a period of three weeks. Despite the poor diffraction of this single crystal, the structure could be unequivocally solved in the C2/c space group, and the obtained crystallographic data confirm the successful formation of the 1D coordination polymer {[Ru­(II)–Cd­(II)­Cl3]­PF6} n , shown in . The Cd­(II) metal ions act as connecting nodes, adopting a trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry, with the two pendant pyridyl groups of the ruthenium­(II) complexes occupying axial positions and the three chloride ions forming the trigonal base. Each 1D polymer chain is homochiral formed from either Δ or Λ configuration ruthenium­(II) complexes.

Despite the poor diffraction of this single crystal, the structure could be unequivocally solved in the C2/c space group, and the obtained crystallographic data confirm the successful formation of the 1D coordination polymer {[Ru(II)-Cd(II)Cl3]PF6} n , shown in . The Cd(II) metal ions act as connecting nodes, adopting a trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry, with the two pendant pyridyl groups of the ruthenium(II) complexes occupying axial positions and the three chloride ions forming the trigonal base. Each 1D polymer chain is homochiral formed from either Δ or Λ configuration ruthenium(II) complexes.

elements.content: Additional nonclassical hydrogen bonds between the chloride groups and adjacent bipyridine and phenanthroline protons bridge adjacent polymer chains of opposite chirality (b) to form 2D sheets, as shown in . Specifically, short contacts are present between the Cl2 atom and the H14ii (symmetry code (ii) = 1 – x, −y, 1 – z) atom of the bipyridine ligand on an adjacent polymer chain (Cl···H contact distance of 2.9 Å) and the H20iii (symmetry code (ii) = 1 – x, y, 1/2 – z) atom of the bipyridine ligand on the same polymer chain (Cl···H contact distance of 2.69 Å) and between Cl1 and H3i (Cl···H contact distance of 2.67 Å; symmetry code (i) = 1/2 – x, 1/2 – y, 1 – z). Strong chloride binding has been recently described between the protons of coordinated pyridyl units and chloride anions, and this example also demonstrates this type of favorable interaction is likely widespread.

elements.content: To confirm the photophysical properties of the ruthenium­(II) complex had been retained in the extended material, solid-state emission spectra and excited-state lifetimes were measured. For reference, [Ru­(phen)2(4) (PF6)2 and Λ-[Ru­(phen)2(4) (PF6)2 were also measured under identical conditions. Bulk samples of {[Ru­(phen)2(4)-CdCl3]­PF6} n and {Λ-[Ru­(phen)2(4)-CdCl3]­PF6} n were prepared by reaction of [Ru­(phen)2(4) (PF6)2 or Λ-[Ru­(phen)2(4) (PF6)2 with excess CdCl2·2.5H2O in methanol to give precipitates of these materials. The data, shown in , shows the emission energy of both the racemic and enantiopure complexes are very similar (674 and 675 nm, respectively), and lower energy than in acetonitrile solution (666 nm; see ). Upon formation of the polymeric structures, the emission of both the racemic and enantiopure complexes was shifted to lower energy (698 and 692 nm, respectively). Additionally, a shortening of the lifetimes was also observed upon forming the polymeric structures for both the [Ru­(phen)2(4) (PF6)2 and Λ-[Ru­(phen)2(4) (PF6)2 systems (racemic: 200 to 160 ns; enantiopure: 312 to 250 ns). This is consistent with the formation of emissive polymers containing [Ru­(phen)2(4)]2+ and Cd­(II) bridging ions.

Bulk samples of {[Ru(phen)2(4)-CdCl3]PF6} n  and {Λ-[Ru(phen)2(4)-CdCl3]PF6} n  were prepared by reaction of [Ru(phen)2(4) (PF6)2 or Λ-[Ru(phen)2(4) (PF6)2 with excess CdCl2⋅2.5H2O in methanol to give precipitates of these materials. The data, shown in , shows the emission energy of both the racemic and enantiopure complexes are very similar (674 and 675 nm, respectively), and lower energy than in acetonitrile solution (666 nm; see ). Upon formation of the polymeric structures, the emission of both the racemic and enantiopure complexes was shifted to lower energy (698 and 692 nm, respectively). Additionally, a shortening of the  lifetimes was also observed upon forming the polymeric structures for both the [Ru(phen)2(4) (PF6)2 and Λ-[Ru(phen)2(4) (PF6)2 systems (racemic: 200 to 160 ns; enantiopure: 312 to 250 ns). We have successfully shown that ruthenium­(II) polypyridyl complexes can be readily decorated with additional pendant pyridyl groups using Pd(0)-mediated cross coupling reactions, which are suitable as supramolecular building blocks for the preparation of more complex molecular architectures. The prepared complexes can also be easily resolved into their respective enantiomeric forms, offering the further prospect of constructing chiral extended structures. The relatively long-lived 3MLCT excited states of the parent ruthenium­(II) polypyridyl complexes are maintained in solution, and we have demonstrated that these photophysical properties can be modulated via the addition of external modulators such as acid, which offers further promising avenues of exploration in terms of applications such as stimuli-responsive switchable photoredox catalysis, which we are currently pursuing.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have successfully shown that ruthenium(II) polypyridyl complexes can be readily decorated with additional pendant pyridyl groups using Pd(0)-mediated cross coupling reactions, which are suitable as supramolecular building blocks for the preparation of more complex molecular architectures. The prepared complexes can also be easily resolved into their respective enantiomeric forms, offering the further prospect of constructing chiral extended structures. The relatively long-lived 3MLCT excited states of the parent ruthenium(II) polypyridyl complexes are maintained in solution, and we have demonstrated that these photophysical properties can be modulated via the addition of external modulators such as acid, which offers further promising avenues of exploration in terms of applications such as stimuli-responsive switchable photoredox catalysis, which we are currently pursuing.
